messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids are space rocks.  
They pass near Earth’s path.  
NASA is the US group that looks at space and the sky.  
These asteroids pass inside seven million kilometres of Earth’s path.  
NASA has a map of 1,400 asteroids.  
NASA thinks none will be a danger in the next 100 years.  
NASA already has technology to track these rocks.  
NASA can guess if they will hit Earth.  
Then NASA can try two ways to protect Earth.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Factual Inaccuracy. The writer's output says “inside seven million kilometres of Earth’s path” but the original states “within 7.5 million kilometres of Earth’s orbit”. Suggestion: correct the distance to “7.5 million kilometres” to match the original text.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids are space rocks.  
They pass inside 7.5 million kilometres of Earth’s orbit.  
NASA is a US space agency.  
NASA has a map of 1,400 of these asteroids.  
NASA thinks none will be a danger for 100 years.  
NASA already has technology to track these objects.  
NASA can guess if they will hit Earth.  
Then NASA can use two ways to protect Earth.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8916 is below the required 0.90, indicating a loss of key lexical detail.
- The technical term "Potentially Hazardous Asteroids" was reduced to the generic "space rocks", dropping the precise label.
- "Make predictions about possible impact" was changed to "guess if they will hit Earth", losing the formal nuance of prediction.
- The phrase "two defence solutions could be launched" became "use two ways to protect Earth", omitting the concept of launching defence solutions.
Suggestion: Restore the term "Potentially Hazardous Asteroids". Replace "guess if they will hit Earth" with "make predictions about possible impact". Include the exact phrase "two defence solutions could be launched" to maintain fidelity.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Hazardous Asteroids are space rocks near Earth's orbit.  
They pass less than 7.5 million kilometres from Earth's orbit.  
NASA is a US space group.  
NASA has a map of 1,400 Hazardous Asteroids.  
NASA thinks none will be a danger for 100 years.  
NASA already has technology to track them.  
NASA can see if one will hit Earth.  
If there is a chance, NASA will use two ways.  
These ways protect Earth.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance. Classifier rated B1. The text uses vocabulary and structures above A2 level.
- The word potentially (in Potentially Hazardous Asteroids) is B2 level and must be replaced.
- The conditional clause “If there is a chance, NASA will use two ways.” is a complex B1 structure.
- The phrase “less than 7.5 million kilometres” includes a large number and comparative beyond A2.
- Sentences contain multiple clauses and connectors other than and, but, so, because.
Suggestion: Replace potentially with simple word like dangerous.
Suggestion: Use only and, but, so, because for connectors.
Suggestion: Break complex sentences into separate simple sentences.
Suggestion: Use small numbers or words to say many instead of huge figures.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Dangerous asteroids are space rocks.  
NASA calls them “Potentially Hazardous Asteroids”.  
They go near Earth’s orbit.  
NASA is a space group in the USA.  
NASA has a map of fourteen hundred of these.  
NASA thinks none will be a danger for one hundred years.  
NASA has technology to track them.  
NASA watches them near Earth.  
NASA sees a hit coming.  
NASA has two ways.  
They protect Earth.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8567 is below the required 0.90. This shows that important lexical details and key terms from the original text were lost or altered.
- The original term “Potentially Hazardous Asteroids” was reduced to “Dangerous asteroids,” losing the technical name and nuance.
- The phrase “make predictions about possible impact” became “NASA sees a hit coming,” which misrepresents the original meaning and adds unwarranted certainty.
- The concept of launching “two defence solutions” was simplified to “NASA has two ways. They protect Earth,” removing the link to impact prediction and defensive action context.
Suggestion: Restore the exact term “Potentially Hazardous Asteroids,” include “predictions about possible impact” instead of a vague hit forecast, and mention “two defence solutions could be launched” to preserve factual and lexical fidelity.

Text saved: Potentially Hazardous Asteroids (PHAs) are rocks in space.  
They pass as close as 7.5 million kilometres to Earth’s path.  
NASA is a group in the USA that studies space.  
NASA has a map of 1,400 PHAs.  
NASA thinks these rocks are not a threat for one hundred years.  
NASA can track these objects with technology.  
NASA can make predictions about possible impact.  
If an impact looks possible, NASA could launch two defence solutions.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance. The text is classified as B2, not A2. Evidence: the word "potentially" is B2 level; "defence solutions" uses the B1 term "defence" and a complex noun phrase; "impact" and "threat" are B1 words. Suggestion: Remove or replace "potentially" with a simpler alternative; replace "defence solutions" with "two ways to protect"; use A2 vocabulary for "impact" (e.g., "hit") and "threat" (e.g., "danger").
